instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01987: What is 820-01987? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message: I have a computer that came in water damaged, powers on with no backlight. Corroded area was around <CAPACITOR>C8560</CAPACITOR>, rest of the board is clean. <RESISTOR>R8452</RESISTOR> was missing w/ no pads & <CHIP>U8472</CHIP> Hole in it. We jumped <RESISTOR>R8452</RESISTOR> to <RESISTOR>R8453</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R8450</RESISTOR>. During the replacement of <CHIP>U8472</CHIP>, <RESISTOR>R8455</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R8481</RESISTOR> may have been blown off. I could only find one resistor. Schematic does not say no stuff for either. Does anyone have a picture of that area of the board or does anyone know if both need to be on the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
"We jumped <RESISTOR>R8452</RESISTOR> to <RESISTOR>R8453</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R8450</RESISTOR>."
Consult schematic, there is no contact between <RESISTOR>R8450</RESISTOR>/53.
Rebuild the traces based on schematic.
All <RESISTOR>R8450</RESISTOR>-53 must be present.

<CHIP>U8472</CHIP> burnt with hole in, T2 could be damaged now.

Replace all damaged components and be sure to get good traces.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
i checked the traces from the board and double checked with the schematic.  can you help me understand because i checked it and i thought it was connected.

Topside of <RESISTOR>R8452</RESISTOR> is connected to <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> which is also connected to <RESISTOR>R8453</RESISTOR>
bottom side of <RESISTOR>R8452</RESISTOR> is connected to <SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL> which is connected to <RESISTOR>R8450</RESISTOR>

if you could explain where i went wrong i would appreciate it!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
"We jumped <RESISTOR>R8452</RESISTOR> to <RESISTOR>R8453</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R8450</RESISTOR>"
This sounds like you've put all 3 resistors in contact; there is no common point.

If you did it as explained in last post, is OK.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message: okay, i put back <RESISTOR>R8455</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R8481</RESISTOR> but i still don't have backlight.  can you help me rule everything else out before i have to replace t2?  the board is booting up and everything else is working exepct backlight.  wouldn't this mean t2 is sill good?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
T2 works, but nobody can assure its backlight adjust output is still good; hope it is.

Did you replace all, including <CHIP>U8472</CHIP>?
Post its voltages.
Do you get <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>?
